description: This is a dummy item.  If you see it something went wrong.
The skull of a human being.  Carrying this around probably isn't going to win you any friends.
The skull of a tiny canine, likely a Chihuahua or another similarly sized dog breed.
The skull of a small canine, likely a small dog breed.
The skull of a wolf or a dog.  Essential material for building an articulated wolf skeleton.
The skull of a what looks like a dog, although it has an extra eye socket.
The skull of a small feline, likely a house cat.
The skull of a medium-sized feline, likely a bobcat.
The skull of a cougar.
The skull of a raccoon.
The skull of a bear.
The skull of an opossum.
The skull of a small rodent, most likely a rat.
The skull of a beaver.
The skull of a pig, either a domestic or a wild one.
The skull of a domestic sheep.
The skull of a goat with the horns still attached.
The skull of a bovine, likely a domestic cow, with the horns still attached.
The skull of a horse.  Given the circumstances you can be pretty sure it was a domestic horse.
The skull of a cervine, either a deer or a reindeer, with the antlers still attached.
The skull of a cervine, with the antlers still attached…  But why does it have eight eye sockets?
The skull of a moose, unmistakable thanks to the antler shape.
The skull of a moose, unmistakable thanks to the antler shape and… tusks?  Okay, maybe this did not belong to a normal moose after all.

Similar in general shape to the characteristic skulls of fellow tyrannosaurs, this massive cranium once belonged to a Gorgosaurus.  Possessing a blunted muzzle and a small crest that rises above and in front of each of the circular eye sockets, the skull is both longer and lower than those found on most large therapods related to it.
//: couldn’t find a dedicated statistic for the weight, so the number utilised here is my best guess and is, as such, likely incorrect.

description: Similar in general shape to the characteristic skulls of fellow tyrannosaurs, this massive cranium once belonged to a Gorgosaurus.  Possessing a blunted muzzle and a small crest that rises above and in front of each of the circular eye sockets, the skull is both longer and lower than those found on most large therapods related to it.  This particular example is not an original specimen, having been cast from plaster, and is, considering your current situation, largely worthless save as a decorative piece.
//: couldn’t find a dedicated statistic for the weight, so the number utilised here is my best guess and is, as such, likely incorrect. Slicing it's weight in half from the real skull for a rough estimation of the lighter weight afforded by its plaster construction.

description: Long, deep, and quite sizable, this Iguanodon-like skull belonged to a specimen of the ornithopod dinosaur Tenontosaurus.  The skull possesses a characteristic beak, which is primarily U-shaped and houses a row of tightly fitted teeth situated at the back of the jaw.  This particular example is not an original specimen, having been cast from plaster, and is, considering your current situation, largely worthless save as a decorative piece.
//: No genuine skull is included, as preserved, museum-quality Tenontosaurus craniums are highly rare and very unlikely to show up in a random New England establishment.
//2: couldn’t find a dedicated statistic for the weight of a replica skull, so the number utilised here is my best guess and is, as such, likely incorrect.

description: a narrow, triangular skull with a vaulted palate and broadly flared jugal bones.  Possessing pronounced skull openings that lower the weight of the overall cranium, dozens of curved teeth, and a robust skull roof, this is the characteristically raptor-like skull of a Deinonychus.

description: This is a slender cranium of modest proportions, possessing large, sideways-facing eye sockets and toothless jaws.  Narrowing to a pointed taper at the snout, this Struthiomimus skull is V-shaped in appearance.
//: Numbers for weight, length and volume calculations taken from a Gallimimus skull: the closest approximation I could find.

description: The skull of a llama.
